awd_titl_txt: CAREER: California Megadroughts in Context: Integrating High Resolution Speleothem Records with Isotope-enabled Climate Models and Translating Climate Data for the K-12 Classroom
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER project generally aims to integrate high-resolution, multi-proxy speleothem records of climate change during the last deglaciation and Holocene from two California caves with isotope-enabled paleoclimate models in an effort to constrain changes in precipitation amount and source and identify the drivers of hydrologic change in California, including severe drought.  Speleothem records (i.e., oxygen and carbon isotopes, crystal fabrics, trace elements, strontium and uranium isotopes) will be developed from cave monitoring.  An isotope-enabled reactive transport modeling tool will be used to parse the multiple interrelated environmental influences on environmental proxies.  This research will help advance speleothem initial uranium isotope ratios, an emerging proxy for infiltration rate, by conducting high-resolution measurements through key climatic transitions and by investigating the spatial and temporal variability of Uranium isotope ratios in cave drip water. 

Central and northern California speleothem records developed in this project will be integrated with other regional records to create time-varying maps of precipitation change along the U.S. west coast. Quantitative comparison of these maps with isotope-enabled climate models for time slices through the last deglaciation and Holocene will help clarify the driving mechanisms behind precipitation change and regional climate variability. Expected outcomes of the research include: 1) development of a history of precipitation variability along the U.S. west coast consisting of overlapping stalagmite records from multiple proxies for extending to 33,000 years before the present; 2) cross-validation of proxy and monitoring data with isotope-enabled reactive transport models 3) evaluation of speleothem initial Uranium isotope ratios as a paleo-infiltration indicator; 4) detailed records of inter-annual to multi-decadal precipitation variability at sites with contrasting modern precipitation responses to ocean-atmosphere oscillations and perspective on the evolution of these patterns through time; 5) evaluation of the driving mechanisms of California precipitation variability, including megadrought conditions, through proxy-model comparisons; and 6) improved understanding of the role of changing moisture source in the development and decay of drought conditions.

The education plan builds on the researcher's ongoing relationship with the School for Science and Math at Vanderbilt University (SSMV) through multi-year mentoring of a team of high school students from the Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools (MNPS) who will conduct field experiments, geochemical research, and ultimately, the creation of an online educational tool for use in Tennessee classrooms.   The goal of the online portal is to present the wealth of climate and paleoclimate data available online in a way that is useful and accessible for teachers, with the hope of transforming the way climate science is taught in K-12 classrooms by making data-driven, immersive learning on this topic more achievable. This project will involve graduate, undergraduates, and high school students to produce an educational product that has the potential for a lasting positive influence on Tennessee science classrooms and beyond.

por.por_cntn:
This Early Career Development Award focused on understanding past climate change in California through the lens of chemical variations in crystalline stalagmites from two California caves. New information about climate and rainfall variability over the past 37,000 years was produced for caves in the Santa Cruz Mountains of central California and near Lake Shasta in northern California. In addition to new records that refine our understanding of western US paleoclimate, this CAREER award has also supported new innovations in stalagmite research. This includes development of novel stalagmite calcium isotope records of paleorainfall amount as well as stalagmite levoglucosan records of fire activity. Our work toward quantitative paleorainfall estimates through calcium isotope records, rooted in monitoring of calcium isotope transformations in the modern cave environment, will provide tangible information for resource planners in California looking for estimates of rainfall change beyond the instrumental record. Our work illuminated the response of coastal California climate to the global perturbations during and leading into the 8.2 kyr event, a ~150 year-long cold snap first noted in Greenland ice core records. Stalagmites from coastal California suggest that the 8.2 kyr event is coincident with an increase in back-to-back extreme wet and dry intervals in California and further indicates that this volatility is accompanied by changes in local vegetations communities and an increase in fire activity. 

This award also partially supported new isotope-enabled general circulation model experiments focused on the Last Glacial Maximum (21,000 years ago) and Heinrich Stadial 1 (16,000 years ago) when North Atlantic records suggest large releases of ice bergs into that part of the global ocean. Both intervals are recognized as times of increased precipitation in the western United States (US).  We investigated how precipitation from atmospheric river storms varied during these intervals and compared the model outcomes with available paleoclimate records to determine the most important drivers for observed climate change during this time. Overall, our work suggests that California climate becomes more volatile and experiences more atmospheric river storms during past intervals when freshwater is entering the North Atlantic Ocean.

This award supported the research of three Masters students, one PhD student, three undergraduates and six high school students from Metro Nashville Public Schools. Students at all levels participated in cave field work. This award resulted in twelve publications in scientific journals and numerous conference presentations by students from the high school through doctoral level.

In collaboration with computer scientists, we developed an online, synchronous learning module for 9th grade Metro Nashville Public School students that was implemented during the Covid19 Pandemic. Integrated climate science and coding activities were designed by a team that included high school interns, undergraduates, and graduate students as well as Earth Science and Computer Science faculty. The climate science training, mentoring, and research experiences that were provided to high school students, undergraduates, and graduate students through this award will have far reaching implications by supporting a more STEM-literate population capable of facing the future scientific challenges.
